subject: Re: [junit] newbie question: how to avoid rerunning fixture code on  every test
msgSnippet: ... And what about the case involving runTest() ?  I haven t done such a clear exploratory piece of code, but if you use a runTest method, each TestCase class
messageBody:
jphedley@... wrote:
>
> Err..... I just spent some time responding to this but my message got lost
> since my mail session expired, POS.
>
> This is definitely a source of confusion that surprises many; even some who
> have worked some time with JUnit.
>
> Each test in your suite(e.g., test_underScore1) corresponds to a new instance
> of child of TestCase (e.g., SomeNameTest). Examine how a TestSuite is
> constructed:
> 1)statically
> public static Test suite(){
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore1"));
> suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore2"));
> return suite;
> }
> 2)dynamically
> public static Test suite(){
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(SomeNameTest.class);
> }

And what about the case involving "runTest()"? I haven't done such a
clear exploratory piece of code, but if you use a runTest method, each
TestCase class appears to be treated as a single test when doing dynamic
suites.
